metadata.sermon_start_end: Palm Sunday is the Trojan horse of the church year. You remember the story from Greek mythology: a huge, splendid wooden horse was accepted by the Trojans as a present from the Greeks [...] they are justified by his grace as a gift, through the redemption which is in Christ Jesus, whom God put forward as an expiation by his blood, to be received by faith. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon centers on the Pauline concept of universal sin. However, it leans heavily on a general 'Pauline' theology rather than the specific nuances of Romans 3 that distinguish it from other chapters. The 'uniqueness' of this specific passage (what can be found nowhere else) is somewhat submerged by general themes of guilt.
quotes: In his letter to the Christians in Rome, St. Paul teaches at length about guilt and innocence.
Paul is quoting one of the Psalms when he says 'there is no one righteous.'
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify what Romans 3:21-25 offers that Romans 5 or 7 does not. Focus more on the 'manifestation' of righteousness apart from the law as a specific event.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher understands the theological framework (universal sin, power of sin), but there is little to no evidence of linguistic or historical-critical work regarding the first readers in Rome. The distinction between 'Jews and Greeks' in the text is mentioned but not exegetically unpacked.
quotes: All human beings, both Jews and Greeks, are under the power of sin...
The position of humanity before God is that of gross impurity confronted by perfect holiness.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific tension between Jewish and Gentile believers in Rome to show why Paul had to insist 'there is no distinction'.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: This is a strong point. The preacher uses very concrete, contemporary examples (9/11, Abu Ghraib, Duke University, 'The Da Vinci Code') to dismantle the myth of innocence. It avoids generalities by naming specific cultural 'zeitgeist' moments.
quotes: The distribution of the photographs from Abu Ghraib two years ago was widely described as 'the end of American innocence.'
Take for instance the current case of the lacrosse team at Duke University.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application remains tied to the text's solution (justification) as much as it is to the text's diagnosis (sin).

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon moves fluidly between the cultural analysis of 'innocence' and the Pauline diagnosis. It avoids the 'block' structure, though the application of the 'Trojan Horse' metaphor dominates the opening more than the text itself.
quotes: Sweeping declarations of innocence contradict a fundamental truth of the Christian faith.
We are besieged not from without, but from within.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the specific vocabulary of the text (e.g., 'expiation', 'glory of God') to drive the contemporary analysis more directly.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon is heavily weighted toward 'misery' (sin as a power), which Dekker allows for specific occasions. Redemption is present as the 'good news for perps.' Gratitude is less visible but implied in the liturgical response.
quotes: Sin is a Power that has seized control of the human race.
But there is only one gospel that has good news for the perps.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'redemption' aspect by explaining how 'justification by grace' specifically answers the 'misery' of the Abu Ghraib/Duke University examples.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon addresses the 'lostness' of the self-righteous (the woman who wouldn't shout 'Crucify him'). It takes the human condition seriously, though the 'narrow way' as a life design is less developed than the diagnosis of the 'broad way' of false innocence.
quotes: Her whole life was organized around the myth of her own innocence. I felt sad for her; her self-righteousness cut her off from the truth.
the wages of sin is death
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Explicitly present the 'narrow way' of faith as a concrete alternative to the 'myth of innocence' in daily life.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos, specifically as the 'only innocent One' who interposes himself. The sermon correctly identifies Christ as the solution for the 'ungodly.'
quotes: He is the only innocent One... He interposed himself between Sin and us.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Strengthen the 'two natures' aspect; show more clearly how Christ being God makes this 'expiation' effective for the world's 'misery'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18.5 minutes, the sermon falls slightly short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum for 'depth.' The breadth of cultural examples is good, but the exegetical depth (Thesis 2) suffers due to the brevity.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section on Romans 3:21-25 to reach the 20-minute threshold and provide more 'breadth' to the 'depth'.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is a strong exercise in cultural diagnosis but falls short of Dekker's rigorous exegetical standards. It successfully dismantles modern myths of innocence using concrete contemporary examples, effectively 'expounding' the hearer. However, it lacks the technical exegetical depth (Hebrew/Greek/Context) required by Thesis 2 and falls just under the required duration for 'depth.'
strengths: Concrete application: The use of Abu Ghraib and the Duke lacrosse case provides a sharp, non-general critique of the human condition.
Psychological insight: It correctly identifies self-righteousness as a form of 'lostness' (Thesis 5/6).
weaknesses: Exegetical thinness: The sermon relies on general Pauline themes rather than a rigorous exposition of the specific Greek text of Romans 3.
Duration: Under the 20-minute threshold, limiting the space for theological breadth.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a functional sermon that excels in application but requires more substantive exegetical grounding to meet Dekker's ideal of the sermon as the 'actualization of the written Word'.
